EINSTEIN PERSONALIZATION
Choosing a Recommendation Type

When configuring a recommender, you can choose between two recommendation types—goal-based recommendations or rule-based recommendations.

The recommendation type defines the method the recommender uses to provide content.  Goal-based recommendations use a deep learning model to produce personalized, targeted recommendations for individual users. Rule-based recommendations use business logic to mathematically determine a list of recommendations based on Data Cloud calculated insights.

This table highlights how these two recommendation types operate and the kind of personalized content each provides.

GOAL-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS	RULE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS
Uses deep learning algorithms on activity and behavioral data associated with a unique individual to provide personalized experiences.	Relies on Calculated Insights (CIs) from the item data graph to rank and sort recommendable content.
Uses deep learning to predict what recommendations to present to an individual to best achieve the selected business goal.	Generates recommendations based on mathematical calculations associated with specific profile attributes (like sales or views), or item attributes (like price, brand, or publish date).
Eligible individuals receive their own, unique set of recommendations, based on what the algorithm determines will accomplish the selected business goal.	Eligible individuals receive recommendations based on attributes included in the selected calculated insight.  
Each recommendation type provides the option of adding filters to either include or exclude items meeting the filter criteria.


Example:

Maximize Revenue – Recommend items based on unique, individual activities (product likes, purchases, browsing history, and so on), and other behavioral metrics, with a business goal of increasing purchase totals.

	

Examples:

Recommend top selling items less than $10.
Recommend the most viewed articles, excluding articles viewed within the last 30 days.
